title: Keibul Lamjao National Park
short_description: The world's only floating national park, home to the dancing deer 'Sangai' on Loktak Lake.
long_description: The Keibul Lamjao National Park is a national park in the Bishnupur district of the state of Manipur in India. It is 40 km2 in area, the only floating park in the world, located in North East India, and an integral part of Loktak Lake. The park is formed by phumdis, which are floating decomposed plant material. It was created in 1977 to preserve the brow-antlered deer or Sangai, which is an endangered subspecies of Eld's deer, found only in this park. The deer's hooves are adapted to walk on the spongy floating land mass.
wildlife_significance: Only natural habitat of the endangered Sangai (Brow-antlered Deer).
major_experiences: Early morning boat ride to spot Sangai
guides_and_tips: Binoculars are essential. The deer camouflage perfectly with the brownish grass.
how_to_reach: By Air: Imphal (53 km). By Road: Taxi from Imphal to Moirang/Sendra.
permits_and_fees: Inner Line Permit (ILP) required for Manipur. Park entry nominal.
conservation_notes: Siltation and hydroponic power projects threaten the water levels and phumdi thickness.
sample_itinerary: Day 1: Arrive Imphal to Sendra. Check in. Sunset over Loktak. Day 2: Early morning boat ride in Keibul Lamjao. Visit Moirang market. Return to Imphal.
safety_tips: Phumdis can be unstable; do not step on them without unmatched local guidance.

opening_hours.time_notes: Sangai come out to feed in early morning.

operating_season.off_season: June to September (Monsoon - high water, difficult visuals)
